Peston said that the organisation "put people on with diametrically opposed views and didn't give their viewers and listeners any help in assessing which one was the loony and which one was the genius. ... Impartial journalism is not giving equal airtime to two people one of whom says the world is flat and the other one says the world is round".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Mark |title=Robert Peston: BBC not impartial during EU referendum campaign |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/oct/06/robert-peston-bbc-not-impartial-during-eu-referendum-campaign |accessdate=6 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=6 October 2018}}</ref>
==Specific allegations==
=== Israeli–Palestinian conflict === Criticism of the BBC's Middle East coverage from supporters of both Israel and the Palestinians led the BBC to commission an investigation and report from a senior broadcast journalist [[Malcolm Balen]], referred to as [[the Balen Report]] and completed in 2004. The BBC's refusal to release the report under the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000]] resulted in a long-running and ongoing legal case.<ref>[http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=43053&c=1 Lords rule Balen report was wrongly blocked under FoI] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306015459/http://www.pressgazette.co.uk/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=43053&c=1 |date=6 March 2012 }} [[Press Gazette]] 11 February 2009</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/feb/11/balen-report-bbc-timeline Timeline: The battle to make BBC publish Middle East coverage report] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 11 February 2009</ref> This led to speculation that the report was damning, as well as to accusations of hypocrisy, as the BBC frequently made use itself of Freedom of Information Act requests when researching news stories.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-444074/BBC-pays-200-000-cover-report-anti-Israel-bias.html |work=[[Daily Mail]] |title=BBC pays £200,000 to 'cover up report on anti-Israel bias' |first=Paul |last=Revoir |date=22 March 2007}}</ref>
After the Balen report, the BBC appointed a committee chosen by the Governors and referred to by the BBC as an "independent panel report" to write a report for publication which was completed in 2006. Chaired by the [[British Board of Film Classification]] president, Sir [[Quentin Thomas]], the committee found that "apart from individual lapses, there was little to suggest deliberate or systematic bias" in the BBC's reporting of the middle east. However, their coverage had been "inconsistent," "not always providing a complete picture" and "misleading", and that the BBC failed to adequately report the hardships of Palestinians living under occupation.<ref name="autogenerated1" /><ref>{{cite news|last=Gibson|first=Owen|date=3 May 2006|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/may/03/israel.broadcasting?INTCMP=SRCH|title=BBC's coverage of Israeli-Palestinian conflict 'misleading|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Byrne|first=Ciar|date=3 May 2006|work=[[The Independent]]|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/bbc-is-criticised-for-misleading-coverage-of-middle-east-476582.html|title=BBC is criticised for misleading coverage of Middle East|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> Reflecting concerns from all sides of the conflict, the committee highlighted certain identifiable shortcomings and made four recommendations, including the provision of a stronger editorial "guiding hand".
Of the report's findings regarding the dearth of BBC reporting of the difficulties faced by the Palestinians, [[Richard Ingrams]] wrote in ''The Independent'' that "No sensible person could quarrel with that judgement".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ingrams|first=Richard|date=6 May 2006|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/richard-ingrams-week-wheres-les-dawson-when-you-need-him-477014.html |title=Richard Ingrams' Week: It doesn't take much to be branded anti-Semitic|work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref> [[Martin Walker (reporter)|Martin Walker]], then the editor of [[United Press International]], agreed that the report implied favouritism towards Israel, but said this suggestion "produced mocking guffaws in my newsroom" and went on to list a number of episodes of (in his view) clear pro-Palestinian bias on the part of the BBC.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/guest_contributors/article715471.ece |work=[[Sunday Times]] |title=The BBC pro-Israeli? Is the Pope Jewish? |first1=Martin |last1=Walker |date=11 May 2006 |accessdate=11 April 2011}}{{subscription required|date=January 2014}}</ref> Writing in ''[[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]]'' magazine, Conservative MP [[Michael Gove]] wrote that the report was neither independent nor objective.<ref>Gove, Michael (25 June 2006) [http://www.prospectmagazine.co.uk/magazine/biasatthebeeb/ ''Bias at the Beeb''] ''Prospect'', June 2006</ref>
Former BBC Middle East correspondent Tim Llewellyn wrote in 2004 that the BBC's coverage allowed an Israeli view of the conflict to dominate, as demonstrated by research conducted by the [[Glasgow Media Group]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/jun/20/israel.broadcasting |work=[[The Guardian]] |title=The story TV news won't tell |date=20 June 2004 |accessdate=30 April 2010 |first=Tim |last=Llewellyn}}</ref>
Douglas Davis, the London correspondent of ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', has accused the BBC of being anti-[[Israel]]. He wrote that the BBC's coverage of the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]] was a "portrayal of Israel as a demonic, criminal state and Israelis as brutal oppressors" and resembled a "campaign of vilification" that had de-legitimised the [[State of Israel]].<ref name="Davis130">Davis, Douglas. "Hatred in the air: the BBC, Israel and Anti-Semitism". in: Iganski, Paul & Kosmin, Barry. (eds) ''A New Anti-Semitism? Debating Judeophobia in 21st century Britain''. Profile Books, 2003, p. 130.</ref> "[[Anglicans for Israel]]", the pro-Israel [[pressure group]], have berated the BBC for apparent anti-Israel bias.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anglicansforisrael.com/docs/2006/05/24/afi-acts-against-bbc-bias/ |title=Anti-Israel bias |work=anglicansforisrael.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021015450/http://www.anglicansforisrael.com/docs/2006/05/24/afi-acts-against-bbc-bias/ |archivedate=21 October 2006 }}</ref>
''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' has criticised the BBC for its coverage of the Middle East. In 2007, the newspaper wrote, "In its international and domestic news reporting, the corporation has consistently come across as naïve and partial, rather than sensitive and unbiased. Its reporting of Israel and Palestine, in particular, tends to underplay the hate-filled Islamist ideology that inspires Hamas and other factions, while never giving Israel the benefit of the doubt."<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml?xml=/opinion/2007/08/20/dl2001.xml Terror victims are BBC licence-payers, too] 20 August 2007</ref>
In April 2004, [[Natan Sharansky]] who was then Israel's minister for diaspora affairs wrote to the BBC accusing its Middle East correspondent, [[Orla Guerin]], as having a "deep-seated bias against Israel" following her description of the Israeli army's handling of the arrest of [[Hussam Abdo]], who was captured with explosives strapped to his chest, as "cynical manipulation of a Palestinian youngster for propaganda purposes."<ref>{{cite news|last=McGreal|first=Chris|title=BBC accused of bias against Israel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/apr/01/bbc.israel|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=1 April 2004|date=1 April 2004}}</ref>
In March 2006 a report about the Arab-Israeli conflict on the BBC's online service was criticised in a BBC Governors Report as unbalanced and creating a biased impression. The article's account of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 242]] in 1967 concerning the [[Six-Day War]] between Israel and a coalition of Egypt, Jordan and Syria "suggested the UN called for Israel's unilateral withdrawal from territories seized during the six-day war, when in fact, it called for a negotiated 'land for peace' settlement between Israel and 'every state in the area'. The committee considered that by selecting only references to Israel, the article had breached editorial standards on both accuracy and impartiality".<ref>{{cite news|last=Dowell|first=Ben|title=BBC online censured for biased Israel story |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/mar/08/digitalmedia.middleeastthemedia|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=8 March 2006|date=8 March 2006}}</ref><ref>[http://www.camera.org/index.asp?x_context=4&x_outlet=12&x_article=1096 "BBC Partially Revises Biased Timeline on Web site"], CAMERA, 10 March 2006</ref>
On 7 March 2008, news anchor Geeta Guru-Murthy clarified significant errors in the BBC's coverage of the [[Mercaz HaRav massacre]] that had been exposed by media monitor [[Committee for Accuracy in Middle East Reporting in America]]. Correspondent Nick Miles had informed viewers that "hours after the attack, Israeli bulldozers destroyed his [the perpetrator's] family home." This was not the case, and other broadcasters showed the east Jerusalem home to be intact and the family commemorating their son's actions.<ref name="Paul">{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Jonny|title=BBC admits inaccuracies in coverage|url=http://www.jpost.com/International//Article.aspx?id=95809|work=[[Jerusalem Post]]|date=22 March 2008|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
On 14 March 2008, the BBC accepted that in an article on their website of an IDF operation that stated "The Israeli air force said it was targeting a rocket firing team. ... UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has condemned Israel's attacks on Palestinian civilians, calling them inappropriate and disproportionate", they should have made reference to what [Ban] said about Palestinian rocket attacks as well as to the excessive use of force by Israel. The article was additionally amended to remove the reference of Israeli 'attacks on civilians' as Ban Ki-Moon's attributed comments were made weeks earlier to the UN Security Council, and not in reference to that particular attack, and in fact, he had never used such terminology.<ref name="Paul"/>
The BBC received intense criticism in January 2009 for its decision not to broadcast a television appeal by aid agencies on behalf of the people of Gaza during the [[2008–2009 Israel–Gaza conflict]], on the grounds that it could compromise the BBC's journalistic impartiality. A number of protesters asserted that this showed pro-Israeli bias,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dearden |first1=Lizzie |title=Hundreds protest against 'BBC pro-Israel bias'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/hundreds-protest-against-bbc-pro-israel-bias-of-gaza-coverage-in-cities-across-the-uk-9609016.html|accessdate=22 January 2016|work=The Independent|date=16 July 2014}}</ref> while some analysts suggested that the BBC's decision in this matter derived from its concern to avoid anti-Israeli bias as analysed in the Balen report.<ref>[http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23628970-details/The+secret+report+at+heart+of+BBC%E2%80%99s+Gaza+paranoia/article.do The secret report at heart of BBC's Gaza paranoia] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120919102629/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23628970-details/The+secret+report+at+heart+of+BBC%E2%80%99s+Gaza+paranoia/article.do |date=19 September 2012 }} ''[[Evening Standard]]'' 27 January 2009</ref> Parties criticising the decision, included [[Church of England]] archbishops, British government ministers and even some BBC employees. More than 11,000 complaints were filed in a three-day span. The BBC's director general, Mark Thompson, explained that the corporation had a duty to cover the Gaza dispute in a "balanced, objective way", and was concerned about endorsing something that could "suggest the backing one side".<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/27/world/europe/27britain.html?scp=1&sq=bbc%20gaza&st=cse "BBC Assailed for Refusing to Carry Gaza Appeal."] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 26 January 2009. Retrieved on 28 January 2009.</ref> Politicians such as [[Tony Benn]] broke the corporation's ban on the appeal and broadcast the Gaza appeal on [[BBC News]], saying that "If the BBC won't broadcast the appeal, then I'm going to do it myself", and adding that "no one [working for the broadcaster] agrees with what the BBC has done".<ref>{{cite news|title=Tony Benn launches own Gaza appeal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/mediamonkeyblog/2009/jan/26/tony-benn-launches-own-gaza-appeal|accessdate=22 January 2016|work=The Guardian|date=26 January 2009}}</ref>
[[Mohamed ElBaradei]], head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], protested the BBC's decision by cancelling interviews scheduled with the company; ElBaradei claimed the refusal to air the aid appeal "violates the rules of basic human decency which are there to help vulnerable people irrespective of who is right or wrong."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7856213.stm |title=IAEA head boycotts BBC over Gaza |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=11 August 2009 |date=28 January 2009}}</ref> The BBC's chief operating officer, Caroline Thomson, affirmed the need to broadcast "without affecting and impinging on the audience's perception of our impartiality" and that in this case, it was a "real issue."<ref>{{cite news|title=Protest over BBC Gaza appeal veto|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7848614.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 January 2009|date=24 January 2009}}</ref>
In response to perceived falsehoods and distortions in a BBC One ''Panorama'' documentary entitled 'A Walk in the Park', transmitted in January 2010, British journalist [[Melanie Phillips]] wrote an open letter in news magazine ''[[The Spectator]]'' to the Secretary of State for Culture, Jeremy Hunt, accusing the BBC of "flagrantly biased reporting of Israel" and urged the BBC to confront the "prejudice and inertia which are combining to turn its reporting on Israel into crude pro-Arab propaganda, and thus risk destroying the integrity of an institution".<ref>{{cite news|title=An open letter to the Culture Secretary|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/melaniephillips/6862780/an-open-letter-to-the-culture-secretary.thtml|work=[[The Spectator]]|date=12 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111228140714/http://www.spectator.co.uk/melaniephillips/6862780/an-open-letter-to-the-culture-secretary.thtml|archivedate=28 December 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2010 the BBC was accused of pro-Israel bias in its documentary about the [[Gaza flotilla raid]]. The BBC documentary concluded that Israeli forces had faced a violent premeditated attack by a group of hardcore IHH activists, who intended to orchestrate a political act to put pressure on Israel. The programme was criticised as "biased" by critics of Israel and the PSC (Palestine Solidarity Campaign) questioned why the IDF boarded the ship at night if it had peaceful intention.<ref>{{cite news |last=Paul |first=Jonny |date=20 August 2010 |title=BBC's flotilla film slammed as 'biased' |url=http://www.jpost.com/LandedPages/PrintArticle.aspx?id=185381 |work=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref> Eyewitness Ken O'Keefe accused the BBC of distorting the capture, medical treatment and ultimate release of three Israeli commandos into a story of heroic self-rescuing commandos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/Opinion%20Editorials/2010/August/19%20o/BBC%20Panorama%20on%20the%20Mavi%20Marmara%20Massacre%20Is%20Israeli%20Propaganda%20By%20Gilad%20Atzmon%20and%20Ken%20O'Keefe.htm |title=BBC Panorama on the Mavi Marmara Massacre Is Israeli Propaganda|date=19 August 2010 |accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref> Anthony Lawson produced a 15-minute video detailing the BBC's alleged bias.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrD9PRKRqRA |title=BBC Bias: Panorama Death in the Med|date=16 August 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2015}}</ref>
In March 2011, Member of Parliament [[Louise Bagshawe]] criticised the inaccuracies and omissions in BBC's coverage of the [[Itamar massacre]] and questioned the BBC's decision not to broadcast this incident on television and barely on radio, and its apparent bias against Israel.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/8402973/A-family-slaughtered-in-Israel-doesnt-the-BBC-care.html |title=A family slaughtered in Israel – doesn't the BBC care? |work=[[Daily Telegraph]] |date=24 March 2011 |first=Louise |last=Bagshawe}}</ref> In his July 2012 testimony to the Parliament, the outgoing Director-General of the BBC [[Mark Thompson (television executive)|Mark Thompson]] admitted that BBC "got it wrong".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/bbc-official-admits-the-network-got-it-wrong-on-fogel-murders/ |title=BBC chief admits the network ‘got it wrong’ on Fogel murders|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=25 June 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014 |agency=JTA}}</ref>
A BBC Editorial Standards Findings issued in July 2011 found that a broadcast on Today on 27 September 2010 that stated "At midnight last night, the moratorium on Israelis building new settlements in the West Bank came to an end. It had lasted for ten months", had breached the Accuracy guideline in respect of the requirement to present output "in clear, precise language", as in fact the moratorium on building new settlements had been in existence since the early 1990s and remained in place.<ref>{{cite web|title=Appeals to the Trust and other editorial issues considered by the Editorial Standards Committee|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/appeals/esc_bulletins/2011/jun.txt|publisher=Editorial Standards Committee|accessdate=July 2011}}</ref>
In December 2011, the BBC caused further controversy after censoring the word 'Palestine' from a song played on [[BBC Radio 1Xtra]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/node/182443/ |title=BBC defends decision to censor the word "Palestine" |work=[[New Statesman]] |first=Samera |last=Shackle |date=2 February 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/may/13/bbc-palestine-lyric-mic-righteous |work=[[The Guardian]] |first=Juliette |last=Garside |title=BBC under fire for 'censoring' Palestine lyric |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
More controversy was caused in April 2012 when the BBC broadcast news of 2,500 Palestinian prisoners who were on hunger strike, with very little overall coverage.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/14/palestinian-prisoners-end-hunger-strike |work=[[The Guardian]] |first=Harriet |last=Sherwood |title=Palestinian prisoners end hunger strike |date=14 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jfjfp.com/?p=30702 |title=BBC slammed for blanking historic hunger strike |publisher=[[Jews for Justice for Palestinians]] |date=19 May 2012 |accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> This resulted in two protests outside the BBC buildings in [[Glasgow]]<ref>{{cite web|author=weareallhanashalabi |url=http://weareallhanashalabi.wordpress.com/2012/04/18/report-on-glasgows-bbc-occupation-and-karamah-hunger-strike-march-2/ |title=Report on Glasgow's BBC Occupation and "Karamah Hunger Strike" March |publisher=weareallhanashalabi.wordpress.com |date=18 April 2012 |accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=January 2014}} and in London.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Colbourne |first1=Sarah |last2=German |first2=Lindsey |last3=Nelsen |first3=Diana |last4=Abdullah |first4=Daud|last5=Rose|first5=Chris|last6=Birawi|first6=Zaher|last7=Sawalha|first7=Mohammed|last8=Bunglawala|first8=Shehnaz|title=Letter to BBC: end your silence on Palestine|url=http://palestinecampaign.org/index7b.asp?m_id=1&l1_id=4&l2_id=24&Content_ID=2594|accessdate=21 January 2016|publisher=Palestine Solidarity Campaign|date=16 May 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920075136/http://palestinecampaign.org/index7b.asp?m_id=1&l1_id=4&l2_id=24&Content_ID=2594|deadurl=yes|archivedate=20 September 2012|via=the [[Wayback Machine]]}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=January 2014}}
During the 2012 Summer Olympics, on their country profiles pages, the BBC listed "East Jerusalem" as the capital of Palestine, and did not list a capital at all for Israel. After public outrage and a letter from Israeli government spokesperson [[Mark Regev]], the BBC listed a "Seat of Government" for Israel in Jerusalem, while adding that most foreign embassies "are in Tel Aviv". It made a parallel change to the listing for "Palestine", listing "East Jerusalem" as the "Intended seat of government".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://honestreporting.com/update-fight-over-bbc-olympic-coverage-intensifies/ |title=Fight Over BBC Olympic Coverage Intensifies |publisher=HonestReporting |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref>
In a response to a reader's criticism on the issue, the BBC replied that the complaints that prompted the changes were "generated by online lobby activity".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/70375/bbc-claims-online-lobby-generated-complaints-over-refusal-identify-israels-capita |title=BBC claims 'online lobby' generated complaints over refusal to identify Israel's capital |work=[[Jewish Chronicle]] |date=25 July 2012 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |first=Marcus |last=Dysch}}</ref> The BBC was also noted for having no coverage whatsoever about the campaign{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} for the IOC to commemorate the 11 killed Israeli athletes from the [[Munich massacre]] in the 1972 Summer Olympics, which was met with repeated refusal by IOC President Jacques Rogge, despite the issue receiving much press by other major news networks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/21/olympics-opening-ceremony-israel-munich-ioc-deny_n_1692378.html |work=[[Huffington Post]] |title=Moment Of Silence For 1972 Munich Victims Denied |date=21 July 2012 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Wilson}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/22/sport/olympics-munich-silence/index.html |work=CNN |title=Olympics head rejects silence for Israeli victims |date=23 July 2012 |first=Richard Allen |last=Greene |accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
According to the poll conducted by Jewish Policy Research on more than 4,000 respondents, nearly 80% of British Jews believes that BBC is biased against Israel. Only 14% of British Jews believes that BBC coverage of Israel is "balanced".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/105966/we-think-bbc-news-biased-against-israel-%E2%80%94-watch-it-anyway |title=We think BBC news is biased against Israel — but watch it anyway|work=[[Jewish Chronicle]] |date=18 April 2013 |accessdate=17 June 2013 |last=Rocker |first=Simon}}</ref>
In 2013, the BBC scheduled to broadcast a documentary film, ''Jerusalem: an Archaeological Mystery Story'', but pulled the film "off the schedule at the last minute." The film "theorizes that many Jews did not leave Jerusalem after the destruction of the Temple, and that many modern-day Palestinians may be in part descended from those Jews".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/culture/article/bbc_slammed_for_pulling_documentary_on_jewish_exodus_from_jerusalem|title=BBC slammed for pulling documentary on Jewish exodus from Jerusalem|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|date=1 May 2013|accessdate=24 January 2014|agency=JTA}}</ref> Simon Plosker of HonestReporting believed that the decision was made not to offend people who are ideologically opposed to Israel by broadcasting a documentary about Jewish history in the region. The BBC's explanation for the sudden schedule change was that the film did not fit with the theme of the season, which was archaeology.
In 2014, an [[op-ed]] in ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' by Raphael Cohen-Almagor criticised BBC for avoiding the word 'terrorism' in connection with violent acts or groups of people considered by various governments or intergovernmental organizations to be terrorists. Cohen-Almagor wrote: "Instead of adhering to one principled definition of terrorism and then employing it across the board, the BBC prefers to sit on the fence, so as to say that it is impossible to differentiate between terrorists and 'freedom fighters', that one person's terrorist might be another's 'freedom fighter'."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cohen-Almagor|first1=Raphael|title=BBC's world without terror|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/BBCs-world-without-terror-384993|accessdate=21 December 2014|agency=The Jerusalem Post|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|date=17 December 2014}}</ref>
In the same year, protesters presented an [[open letter]] from the [[Palestinian Solidarity Foundation]], [[Stop the War Coalition]], the [[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]] and other groups to Lord Hall, Director General of the BBC; the letter accused the broadcaster of presenting Israeli attacks on Gaza as a result of rocket fire from [[Hamas]], without giving any other context. This letter was signed by notable individuals, such as [[Noam Chomsky]], [[John Pilger]] and [[Ken Loach]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sign our open letter to the BBC|url=http://www.palestinecampaign.org/sign-open-letter-bbc/|accessdate=22 January 2016|work=Palestinian Solidarity Campaign|date=9 July 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, [[Fraser Steel]] – head of the Editorial Complaints Unit of the BBC – upheld complaints that it had breached impartiality guidelines in an interview with [[Moshe Ya'alon]], who was then the Israeli defence minister.<ref name=72a5>[http://on.rt.com/su2rza "BBC admits Israeli defense minister interview breached impartiality rules "], ''RT International'', 3 June 2015. Accessed 22 January 2016.</ref> Ya'alon claimed on the ''Today'' programme that Palestinians "enjoy already political independence" and "have their own political system, government, parliament, municipalities and so forth", claiming that Israel had no desire "to govern them whatsoever".<ref name=72a5 /> The [[Palestine Solidarity Campaign]] objected to these claims, saying: "Palestinians don't have political independence. They live under occupation and, in Gaza, under siege."<ref name=72a5 /> Filmmaker and activist [[Ken Loach]] sent a letter via the Campaign, saying that: "You understand, I’m sure, that this interview is a serious breach of the requirement for impartiality. Unlike all other ''Today'' interviews, the minister was allowed to speak without challenge. Why?"<ref name=72a5 />
After the [[June 2017 Jerusalem attack]], the BBC reported it as "Three Palestinians killed after deadly stabbing in Jerusalem." After being inundated with complaints, the BBC news on-line changed the headline.<ref>{{cite news |date=17 June 2017 |title=BBC's shameful headline |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/231163 |website=Arutz Sheva |access-date=18 June 2017}}</ref>
=== Iraq and the Hutton Inquiry === The BBC was criticised for its coverage of the events before the [[Iraq War|invasion of Iraq, in 2003]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/nolavconsole/ukfs_news/hi/bb_rm_fs.stm?news=1&bbram=1&bbwm=1&nbram=1&nbwm=1&nol_storyid=6204797 | title = Viewers most common complaints of 2006 | author = BBC NewsWatch | format = Video | date = 22 December 2006 | accessdate = 21 January 2007 }}</ref> The controversy over what it described as the "sexing up" of the case for war in Iraq by the government, led to the BBC being heavily criticised by the [[Hutton Inquiry]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.the-hutton-inquiry.org.uk/ | title = Investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death of Dr. David Kelly | author = Lord Hutton | authorlink = Brian Hutton, Baron Hutton | accessdate = 11 November 2006}}</ref> although this finding was much disputed by the British press, who branded it as a government [[Whitewash (censorship)|whitewash]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/europe/01/29/hutton.press | title = UK press mauls Hutton 'whitewash' | publisher = CNN | date = 29 January 2004 | accessdate = 11 November 2006}}</ref><ref>CNN: [http://edition.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/europe/01/29/hutton.press/ UK press mauls Hutton 'whitewash'], 29 January 2004 (on the reaction of the British press to the final report)</ref>
The BBC's chairman and director general both resigned following the inquiry, and its vice-chairman Lord Ryder made a public apology to the government – which the Liberal Democrat [[Norman Baker]] MP described as "of such capitulation that I wanted to throw up when I heard it".<ref>Baker, Norman: ''The Strange Death of David Kelly'', London: Methuen, 2007</ref>
=== 2006 Lebanon War === During the [[2006 Lebanon War]], Israeli diplomatic officials boycotted BBC news programmes, refused interviews, and excluded BBC reporters from briefings because Israeli officials believed the BBC's reporting was biased, stating "the reports we see give the impression that the BBC is working on behalf of [[Hezbollah]] instead of doing fair journalism".<ref>{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Gil |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1154525841951&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=Jerusalem Post article on BBC coverage of the Israel-Lebanon conflict |work=[[Jerusalem Post]] |date=10 August 2006 |accessdate=29 May 2011 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Fran Unsworth]], head of BBC News gathering, defended the coverage in an article for ''Jewish News.com''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.totallyjewish.com/news/jewish_news_letters/?content_id=4090 |title=Totally Jewish response to Francesca Unsworth |publisher=Totallyjewish.com |date=30 June 2006 |accessdate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606080124/http://www.totallyjewish.com/news/jewish_news_letters/?content_id=4090 |archivedate=6 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== The Balen Report === {{Main article|The Balen Report}} The BBC eventually overturned a ruling by the Information Tribunal rejecting the BBC's refusal to release the Balen report to Steven Sugar, a member of the public, under the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information Act]] on the grounds that it was held for the purposes of journalism. The report examines BBC radio and television broadcasts covering the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]] and was compiled in 2004 by [[Malcolm Balen]], a senior editorial adviser.
On 10 October 2006, ''The Daily Telegraph''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1531443/BBC-mounts-court-fight-to-keep-critical-report-secret.html|title=BBC mounts court fight to keep 'critical' report secret|date=15 October 2006|accessdate=24 January 2014|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> claimed that "The BBC has spent thousands of pounds of licence payers' money trying to block the release of a report which is believed to be highly critical of its Middle East coverage. The corporation is mounting a landmark High Court action to prevent the release of The Balen Report under the Freedom of Information Act, despite the fact that BBC reporters often use the Act to pursue their journalism. The action will increase suspicions that the report, which is believed to run to 20,000 words, includes evidence of anti-Israeli bias in news programming." ''The Times'' reported in March 2007 that "critics of the BBC" were interested in knowing if the Balen Report "includes evidence of bias against Israel in news programming."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article1575543.ece|title=BBC asks court to block Israel report |first=Michael|last=Herman|work=[[The Times]]|date=27 March 2007}}{{subscription required|date=January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article2398870.ece |title=BBC fights to suppress internal report into allegations of bias against Israel |first=Andy |last=McSmith |work=[[The Independent]] |date=28 March 2007 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013035628/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article2398870.ece |archivedate=13 October 2008}}</ref>
First, the Information Commissioner ruled in favour of the BBC. Mr Sugar appealed to the Information Tribunal, who overturned the decision on the basis that the report was not for the purposes of journalism. The BBC appealed on two grounds, firstly that the Information Tribunal did not have jurisdiction in these circumstances, and secondly, even if they did, the report was for the purposes of journalism. On 27 April 2007 the High Court agreed that the Information Tribunal had no jurisdiction (thus reinstating the Information Commissioner's ruling in favour of the BBC) and therefore they did not rule on the second ground for appeal. The BBC issued a press release which included the following statement:<blockquote>"The BBC's action in this case had nothing to do with the fact that the Balen report was about the Middle East – the same approach would have been taken whatever area of news output was covered."<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2007/04_april/27/balen.shtml 'Balen report: BBC successful in High Court challenge'] BBC Press Office 27 April 2007</ref></blockquote>
But then, on 11 February 2009 the House of Lords (then the UK's highest court) overruled them, stating that the Information Tribunal did have jurisdiction, and referred the case back to the High Court to rule on the other ground. Sugar was then reported as saying:<blockquote>"It is sad that the BBC felt it necessary to spend hundreds of thousands of pounds of public money fighting for three years to try to load the system against those requesting information from it. I am very pleased that the House of Lords has ruled that such obvious unfairness is not the result of the Act."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/feb/11/lawyer-hails-lords-bbc-middle-east|title=Lawyer hails Lords BBC Middle East report ruling as a victory|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 February 2009|accessdate=24 January 2014|first=Afua|last=Hirsch}}</ref></blockquote>
However, on 2 October 2009, the High Court ruled that the BBC was ''not'' required to disclose the Balen Report, because it was partly for the purposes of journalism, and in spite of appeals by Steven Sugar and, after his death, his wife, both the Court of Appeal, on 23 June 2010, and the Supreme Court, on 23 November 2011, agreed with that ruling, thus clarifying the law applying to any similar reports in the future.
In 2010 it was reported by the Journalism.co.uk website, after a Freedom of Information request, that the BBC had spent £270,867.12 in legal fees since 2005 in sustaining its refusal of the request to publicly release the Balen Report.<ref>Laura Oliver [https://www.journalism.co.uk/news/bbc-reveals-legal-costs-of-freedom-of-information-requests/s2/a540689/ "BBC reveals legal costs of freedom of information requests"], journalism.co.uk, 22 September 2010</ref><ref>Two years later, according to a FOI request by The Commentator website, the figure had risen to £330,000, see Simon Rocker [http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/76841/bbc-spent-£330000-supressing-balen-report "BBC spent £330,000 suppressing Balen report"], ''The Jewish Chronicle'', 30 August 2012</ref>
=== Barbara Plett's tears for Yasser Arafat === During the BBC programme ''[[From Our Own Correspondent]]'' broadcast on 30 October 2004, [[Barbara Plett]] described herself crying when she saw a frail [[Yasser Arafat]] being evacuated to France for medical treatment.<ref name=plett1>Plett, Barbara (30 September 2004) [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/3966139.stm "Yasser Arafat's unrelenting journey"], BBC News, 30 October 2004. Retrieved 22 October 2006</ref> This led to "hundreds of complaints" to the BBC, and suggestions that the BBC was biased. [[Andrew Dismore]], the MP for Hendon, accused Plett of "sloppy journalism", and commented that "this shows the inherent bias of the BBC against Israel".<ref>{{cite news|title=Radio 4 broadcast under attack as corporation faces fresh accusations of failing to be impartial |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1476070/Radio-4-broadcast-under-attack-as-corporation-faces-fresh-accusations-of-failing-to-be-impartial.html|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=7 November 2004 |first1=Chris |last1=Hastings |first2=Charlotte |last2=Edwardes |first3=Katharine|last3=Houreld|date=7 November 2004}}</ref><ref name="Guardian5">{{cite news|last=Gibson|first=Owen|date=26 November 2005 |url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/site/story/0,14173,1651260,00.html|title=BBC bias complaint upheld|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=8 January 2007}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2005">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4471494.stm|title=Arafat report 'broke BBC rules'|publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=25 November 2005|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
[[BBC News]] defended Plett in a statement saying that her reporting had met the high standards of "fairness, accuracy and balance" expected of a BBC correspondent.<ref name=plett1 /><ref name="Guardian">Gibson, Owen (26 November 2005). "[http://media.guardian.co.uk/site/story/0,14173,1651260,00.html BBC bias complaint upheld]". ''[[The Guardian]]''. URL accessed on 22 October 2006.</ref><ref name="TomGross">[[Tom Gross|Gross, Tom]] (28 November 2005). [http://www.tomgrossmedia.com/mideastdispatches/archives/000605.html BBC sanctions reporter who cried for Arafat (& "Hitler" running in Fatah primaries)] Retrieved 30 December 2006.</ref> Initially, a complaint of bias against Plett was rejected by the BBC's head of editorial complaints. However, almost a year later, on 25 November 2005, the programme complaints committee of the BBC governors partially upheld the complaints, ruling that Plett's comments "breached the requirements of due impartiality".<ref name="Guardian5"/> Despite initially issuing a statement in support of Plett, the BBC director of news [[Helen Boaden]] later apologised for what she described as "an editorial misjudgment". The governors praised Boaden's speedy response and reviewed the BBC's stance on the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]].<ref name="Guardian5"/><ref name="autogenerated2005"/><ref name="TomGross"/>
===Jeremy Bowen=== In April 2009, the Editorial Standards Committee of the [[BBC Trust]] published a report on three complaints brought against two news items involving [[Jeremy Bowen]], the Middle East Editor for [[BBC News]].<ref name="ESCReport">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/appeals/esc_bulletins/2009/mar.pdf |title=Editorial Standards Findings |format=PDF |accessdate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514185245/http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/appeals/esc_bulletins/2009/mar.pdf |archivedate=14 May 2011 }}</ref> The complaints included 24 allegations of inaccuracy or partiality of which three were fully or partially upheld.<ref name="ESCReport" /><ref name=lerman160409>[[Antony Lerman]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 16 April 2009, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/apr/16/jeremy-bowen-bbc-middle-east What did Jeremy Bowen do wrong?]</ref><ref>BBC News Online, 4 June 2007, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/6709173.stm How 1967 defined the Middle East]</ref> The BBC Trust's editorial standards committee found that Bowen's radio piece "had stated his professional view without qualification or explanation, and that the lack of precision in his language had rendered the statement inaccurate". They opined that the online article should have explained the existence of alternative views and that it breached the rules of impartiality. However, the report did not accuse Bowen of bias. The website article was amended and Bowen did not face any disciplinary measures.<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC's Jeremy Bowen breached guidelines on accuracy in Israel reports|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/5158689/BBCs-Jeremy-Bowen-breached-guidelines-on-accuracy-in-Israel-reports.html|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]] |date=15 April 2009|accessdate=24 January 2014 }}</ref>
=== Pro-Muslim bias === [[Hindu]] and [[Sikh]] leaders in the United Kingdom have accused the BBC of pandering to Britain's Muslim community by making a disproportionate number of programmes on Islam at the expense of covering other Asian religions,<ref name="promuslim">{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/sikhs-and-hindus-accuse-bbc-of-promuslim-bias-922482.html |work=[[The Independent]] | title=Sikhs and Hindus accuse BBC of pro-Muslim bias | first=Jerome | last=Taylor | date=8 September 2008 | accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref> such as [[Sikhism]] and [[Hinduism]]. However, in a letter sent in July to the Network of Sikh Organizations (NSO), the head of the BBC's Religion and Ethics, Michael Wakelin, denied any biases on their part.<ref name="Indy Pro-Muslim">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Jerome|title=Sikhs and Hindus accuse BBC of pro-Muslim bias|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/tv-radio/sikhs-and-hindus-accuse-bbc-of-pro-muslim-bias-922482.html|accessdate=21 January 2016|work=The Independent|date=7 September 2008|language=en-GB|quote=In a letter sent in July to the NSO, the head of the BBC's Religion and Ethics, Michael Wakelin, denied that there was any bias. He said the demographic makeup of Britain meant that Britain's 1.6 million Muslims outnumber Hindus and Sikhs by two to one. "Therefore," he wrote, "if Muslims get 60 minutes a year, the Sikhs and Hindus should share 30 minutes each." Further content on Islam, he added, was "no doubt sparked by the interest in the faith following 9/11".}}</ref> A spokesman for the BBC said the broadcaster was committed to representing all of Britain's faiths and communities.<ref name="Indy Pro-Muslim" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Farmer|first1=Ben|title=BBC favours Muslims, complain Hindus and Sikhs|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/2703863/BBC-favours-Muslims-complain-Hindus-and-Sikhs.html|accessdate=21 January 2016|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=8 September 2008}}</ref>
However, a number of MPs, including [[Rob Marris]] and [[Keith Vaz]], called on the BBC to do more to represent Britain's minority faiths. "I am disappointed," said Vaz. "It is only right that as licence fee payers all faiths are represented in a way that mirrors their make-up in society. I hope that the BBC addresses the problem in its next year of programming."<ref name="promuslim"/>
=== Arab Spring === The overly positive coverage by BBC of the [[Arab Spring]] was criticised both from within and outside of the corporation. In June 2012, the head of news Helen Boaden admitted that the coverage was "over-excited". She attributed this to reporters [[Embedded journalism|embedded]] with the rebels, who produced reports which are "too emotive" and "veering into opinion".<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2164536/BBCs-coverage-Arab-Spring-sporadic-ignoring-uprisings-failed-favour-big-stories-Libya-Egypt.html Our coverage of the Arab Spring was over-excited, admits BBC], ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 27 June 2012.</ref>
In June 2012, the BBC admitted making "major errors" in its coverage of the unrest.<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC admits errors in Bahrain unrest coverage|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/MEDIA_219748.html|accessdate=1 July 2012|work=Trade Arabia|date=29 June 2012}}</ref> In an 89-page report, 9 pages were devoted to the BBC's coverage of Bahrain and included admissions that the BBC had "underplayed the sectarian aspect of the conflict" and "not adequately convey the viewpoint of supporters of the monarchy" by "[failing] to mention attempts by Crown Prince" Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa to "establish dialogue with the opposition". The report added that "the government appears to have made a good-faith effort to de-escalate the crisis" in particular during a period when the BBC's coverage of the unrest dropped substantially and that many people had complained that their coverage was "utterly one-sided".<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC admits errors in unrest coverage|url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=333054|accessdate=1 July 2012|work=Gulf News Daily|date=29 June 2012}}</ref>
===Indophobia=== In 2008, the BBC was criticised by some for referring to the men who carried out the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks]] as "gunmen" rather than "terrorists".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/Content/Dec222008/editpage20081221108056.asp |accessdate=11 September 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2008/dec/14mumterror-mj-akbar-slams-bbc-for-biased-coverage-of-mumbai-terror-attack.htm |title='The BBC cannot see the difference between a criminal and a terrorist' |publisher=Rediff.com |first=Sheela |last=Bhat|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/british-biased-corporation-terrorists-in-london-gunmen-in-mumbai/393560/ |title=British Biased Corporation? Terrorists in London, gunmen in Mumbai |work=[[The Indian Express]] |first=Mihir S.|last=Sharma |date=3 December 2008 |accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> This follows a steady stream of complaints from India that the BBC has an [[Indophobic]] bias that stems from a culturally ingrained racism against Indians arising from the [[British Raj]].{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} [[Rediff]] reporter Arindam Banerji has chronicled what he argues are numerous cases of Indophobic bias from the BBC regarding reportage, selection bias, misrepresentation, and fabrications.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}
In protest against the use of the word "gunmen" by the BBC, journalist [[M. J. Akbar|Mobashar Jawed "M.J." Akbar]] refused to take part in an interview following the [[November 2008 Mumbai attacks|Mumbai terror attacks]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/144904/Biased-Broadcasting-Corp-also-known-as-BBC.html |title=Biased Broadcasting Corp also known as BBC |work=The Pioneer |accessdate=16 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609210854/http://www.dailypioneer.com/144904/Biased-Broadcasting-Corp-also-known-as-BBC.html |archivedate=9 June 2009 }}</ref> and criticised the BBC's reportage of the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=102417|title= Biting the BBC bullet|first= M. J.|last= Akbar|date= 22 December 2008|publisher= [[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)]]|accessdate= 28 December 2011|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20121212111342/http://www.international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=102417|archivedate= 12 December 2012|df= dmy-all}} </ref> British parliamentarian [[Stephen Pound]] has supported these claims, referring to the BBC's whitewashing of the terror attacks as "the worst sort of mealy mouthed posturing. It is desperation to avoid causing offence which ultimately causes more offence to everyone."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/bbc-flayed-for-not-terming-mumbai-gunmen-as/393175/ |title=BBC flayed for not terming Mumbai gunmen as terrorists |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2 December 2008 |accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
A controversial report from BBC accused India of sponsoring Pakistan's MQM party, a domestic party based out of Karachi, to fund anti-Pakistani activities. However, the only sources BBC managed to mention for this report was "authoritative Pakistani source", rather than independent investigation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-33148880|title=Pakistan's MQM 'received Indian funding'|last=Bennett-Jones|first=Owen|date=2015-06-24|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-03}}</ref> The flawed reporting was severely criticized by India and other prominent journalists like [[Barkha Dutt]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/mqm-militants-being-funded-by-indias-raw-claims-controversial-bbc-report-2310820.html|title=Pakistan's MQM militants being funded by India's RAW, claims controversial BBC report - Firstpost|date=2015-06-25|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-03}}</ref> Expectedly, the pro-Pakistan and anti-Indian report was extensively circulated in Pakistani domestic media to fuel propaganda and conspiracy theories.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1190175|title=India provided funds to MQM, claims BBC report|last=Dawn.com|date=2015-06-24|access-date=2016-10-03}}</ref>
Writing for ''[[The Hindu]] Business Line'', reporter Premen Addy criticises the BBC's reportage on South Asia as consistently [[anti-India]] and pro-[[Islamist]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blonnet.com/businessline/2001/05/22/stories/042255pr.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070517153830/http://www.blonnet.com/businessline/2001/05/22/stories/042255pr.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 May 2007 |title=Punchy start to the British election |publisher=Blonnet.com |date=22 May 2001 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |first=Premen |last=Addy }}</ref> and that they underreport India's economic and social achievements, as well as political and diplomatic efforts, and disproportionately highlight and exaggerate problems in the country. In addition, Addy alludes to discrimination against Indian anchors and reporters in favour of Muslim [[Pakistan]]i and [[Bangladesh]]i ones who are hostile to India.
Writing for the 2008 edition of the [[peer-reviewed]] ''Historical Journal of Film, Radio and Television'', [[Alasdair Pinkerton]] analyses the coverage of India by the BBC since India's independence from British rule in 1947 until 2008. Pinkerton observes a tumultuous history involving allegations of [[anti-India]] bias in the BBC's reportage, particularly during the [[cold war]], and concludes that the BBC's coverage of [[South Asian]] geopolitics and economics shows a pervasive and hostile [[anti-India]] bias due to the BBC's alleged [[imperialist]] and [[Neocolonialism|neo-colonialist]] stance.<ref>{{cite journal | first = Alasdair | last = Pinkerton | date=October 2008 | title = A new kind of imperialism? The BBC, cold war broadcasting and the contested geopolitics of south asia | journal = Historical Journal of Film, Radio and Television | volume = 28 | issue = 4 | pages = 537–555 | doi = 10.1080/01439680802310324 }}</ref>
Journalist [[Christopher Booker]] has also criticized the BBC for its coverage of India-related matters. He concludes that the BBC's efforts to reinforce [[Stereotypes of South Asians]] has been directly responsible for damaging the image of India, and encouraging racist incidents against Indians, such as the [[Leipzig University internship controversy]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Booker|first1=Christopher|title=Why to blacken India on rape do they have to omit the facts?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/11472416/Why-to-blacken-India-on-rape-do-they-have-to-omit-the-facts.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=14 Mar 2015|accessdate=26 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Anti-Hindu bias ===
[[Hindu]] groups in the United Kingdom have accused the BBC of [[anti-Hindu]] bigotry and whitewashing [[Islamist]] hate groups that demonise the [[British Indian]] minority.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/storyOld.php?storyId=42169 |title=BBC coverage biased, say British Hindus |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2 March 2004 |accessdate=24 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515113814/http://www.indianexpress.com/storyOld.php?storyId=42169 |archivedate=15 May 2011 }}</ref>
In 2005, the Vivekananda Centre London and the Hindu Council(UK) reported an institutional anti Hindu bias and stated that "Anything that may show Hinduism in a poor light is immediately picked up by the BBC programme makers, while anything that may show Hinduism in a glorious light remains ignored by the BBC."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nlXb_Po4P6QC&lpg=PP1&ots=1giDW85EXg&dq=Further%20issues%20for%20BBC%20charter%20review%3A%202nd%20report%20of%20session%202005-06&pg=PA473#v=onepage&q=Further%20issues%20for%20BBC%20charter%20review:%202nd%20report%20of%20session%202005-06&f=false|title=Further Issues for BBC Charter Review|work=google.co.in}}</ref>
In March 2012, the BBC referred to the Hindu festival of [[Holi]] as a "filthy festival". The Webster New World Dictionary defines "filthy" as "full of filth, disgustingly foul; grossly obscene; morally vicious or corrupt". The BBC has since apologised for the offence caused.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/articles/321795/20120330/bbc-controversy-holi-filthy-festival-hindu-criticizes.htm| title=BBC Calls Holi A ‘Filthy Festival’| last=Singh| first=W. Rorrkychand| date=30 March 2012| publisher=[[International Business Times]]| accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
=== Anti-Sikh inclination===
In 2009, the BBC Asian Network angered Sikhs for a show in which Muslim presenter [[Adil Ray]] expressed that Sikhs should not always carry their [[kirpan]], a ceremonial dagger and key item of their faith. The BBC rejected the charge, but deleted the show from their website.<ref name=sikh>{{cite news|title=UK Sikhs accuse BBC of racism|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-08-20/uk/28188663_1_kirpan-uk-sikhs-sikh-community|accessdate=24 January 2014|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=20 August 2009|agency=PTI|first=W. Rorrkychand |last=Singh}}</ref>
=== Anti-American bias === In October 2006, Chief Radio Correspondent for BBC News since 2001<ref>{{cite web | title = BBC World Home Page |publisher=BBC News | url = http://www.bbcworld.com/content/template_clickpage.asp?pageid=178 | accessdate = 2 November 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061028012718/http://www.bbcworld.com/content/template_clickpage.asp?pageid=178 |archivedate = 28 October 2006}}</ref> and [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] correspondent [[Justin Webb]] said that the BBC is so biased against America that deputy director general [[Mark Byford]] had secretly agreed to help him to "correct" it in his reports, and that the BBC treated America with scorn and derision and gave it "no moral weight".<ref name="MoSBiasedBBC"/><ref>{{cite news | title = Cut & paste: A public broadcaster acknowledges its left-wing bias |work=[[The Australian]] | date = 1 November 2006 | url = http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,20684585-7583,00.html | accessdate = 2 November 2006 }}{{subscription required|date=January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Yes, we are biased on religion and politics, admit BBC executives | publisher = Evening Standard | date = 22 October 2006 | url = http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23371706-details/Yes,%20we%20are%20biased%20on%20religion%20and%20politics,%20admit%20BBC%20executives/article.do | accessdate = 2 November 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070622200808/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-23371706-details/Yes%2C%20we%20are%20biased%20on%20religion%20and%20politics%2C%20admit%20BBC%20executives/article.do | archivedate = 22 June 2007 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In April 2007, Webb presented a three-part series for BBC Radio 4 called ''Death to America: Anti Americanism Examined'' in which he challenged a common perception of the United States as an international bully and a modern-day imperial power.<ref>{{cite news|title='Death to US': Anti-Americanism examined|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6547881.stm|date=12 April 2007|accessdate=24 January 2014|work=[[BBC News Online]]}}</ref>
Conservative American news commentator [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] has repeatedly sought to draw attention to what he calls the BBC's "inherent [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] culture."<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,284353,00.html | title =The Far Left, Angelina Jolie and FOX News | work= [[Fox News Channel]] | date = 19 June 2007 | accessdate = 24 January 2014 |first=Bill |last=O'Reilly}}</ref>
=== ''Secret Agent'' documentary === On Thursday 15 July 2004 the BBC broadcast a documentary on the far right [[British National Party]] where undercover reporter [[Jason Gwynne]] infiltrated the BNP by posing as a [[football hooligan]].<ref> {{cite news | last =Utley | first = Tom | title = The BNP is thoroughly nasty, so why did 750,000 people vote for it? |work=[[Daily Telegraph]] | date = 16 July 2004 | url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml?xml=/opinion/2004/07/16/do1601.xml&sSheet=/opinion/2004/07/16/ixopinion.html | accessdate = 25 April 2007}} </ref><ref> {{cite news | title = Going undercover in the BNP | date = 15 July 2004 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/3896213.stm | work = [[BBC News Online]] | accessdate = 24 January 2014 }} </ref> The programme resulted in [[Mark Collett]] and [[Nick Griffin]], the leader of the party, being charged for [[inciting racial hatred]] in April 2005, for statements which included Griffin describing Islam as a "wicked, vicious faith," Collett describing [[asylum seekers]] as "a little bit like cockroaches" and saying "let's show these ethnics the door in 2004." Griffin and Collett were found not guilty on some charges at the first trial in January 2006, but the jury failed to reach a verdict on the others, so a retrial was ordered.<ref>{{cite news | title = BNP duo to face race hate retrial | work = [[BBC News Online]] | date = 3 February 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/west_yorkshire/4672792.stm | accessdate = 26 April 2007 }} </ref>
At the retrial held in November 2006 all of the defendants were found not guilty on the basis that the law at the time did not consider those who follow Islam or Christianity to be a protected group with respect to racial defamation laws.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news | title = BNP leader cleared of race hate |publisher=BBC News | date = 10 November 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bradford/6135060.stm | accessdate = 26 April 2007 }} </ref> Shortly after this case, British law was amended to outlaw incitement to hatred against a religious group (see [[Racial and Religious Hatred Act 2006]]).
The BNP believe this was an attempt to "Discredit the British National Party as a party of opposition to the Labour government."<ref> {{cite news | title = Free Speech Two update | publisher = [[British National Party]] | date = 14 January 2006 | url = http://www.bnp.org.uk/news_detail.php?newsId=731 | accessdate = 28 April 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070313013814/http://www.bnp.org.uk/news_detail.php?newsId=731 |archivedate = 13 March 2007}} </ref>
After the second trial, Nick Griffin described the BBC as a "Politically correct, politically biased organisation which has wasted licence-fee payers' money to bring two people in a legal, democratic, peaceful party to court over speaking nothing more than the truth."<ref name=autogenerated2 />
=== ''Jerry Springer: The Opera'' === In January 2005, the BBC aired ''[[Jerry Springer: The Opera]]'', ultimately resulting in around 55,000 complaints to the BBC from those upset at the opera's alleged blasphemies against Christianity. In advance of the broadcast, which the BBC had warned "contains language and content which won't be to some tastes" [[mediawatch-uk]]'s director [[John Beyer]] wrote to the Director General urging the BBC to drop the programme, saying "Licence fee payers do not expect the BBC to be pushing back boundaries of taste and decency in this way." The BBC issued a statement saying: "As a public service broadcaster, it is the BBC's role to broadcast a range of programmes that will appeal to all audiences – with very differing tastes and interests – present in the UK today."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4147801.stm |title=BBC urged to axe Springer opera |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=5 January 2005|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
Before the broadcast, some 150 people bearing placards protested outside the [[BBC Television Centre]] in [[Shepherd's Bush]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4154071.stm |title=Protests as BBC screens Springer |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=10 January 2005 |accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> On the Monday following the broadcast, which was watched by some two million viewers, ''[[The Times]]'' announced that BBC executives had received death threats after their addresses and telephone numbers were posted on the ''[[Christian Voice (UK)|Christian Voice]]'' website. The Corporation had received some 35,000 complaints before the broadcast, but reported only 350 calls following the broadcast, which were split between those praising the production and those complaining about it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article410579.ece |title=Security guards step in after Springer opera death threats|work=[[The Times]] |date=10 January 2005 |accessdate=30 August 2005}}{{subscription required|date=January 2014}}</ref>
One Christian group attempted to bring private criminal prosecutions for [[Blasphemy law in the United Kingdom|blasphemy]] against the BBC,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4161109.stm |title=Group to act over Springer opera |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=10 January 2005 |accessdate=30 August 2007}}</ref> and another demanded a judicial review of the decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4188403.stm|title=Second action over Springer opera|work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=20 January 2005 |accessdate=30 August 2007}}</ref>
In March 2005, the [[Board of Governors of the BBC|BBC's Board of Governors]] convened and considered the complaints, which they rejected by a majority of 4 to 1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/entertainment/4393533.stm |title=BBC rejects Springer complaints|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=30 March 2005|accessdate=30 August 2007}}</ref> The subsequent refusal of the BBC to reproduce the actual [[Muhammad cartoons]] in its coverage of the controversy concerning them convinced many that the BBC follows an unstated policy of freely broadcasting defamation of Christianity which it would not allow in the case of any other religion.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Finding the right balance | work=[[BBC News Online]] | date = 3 February 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/newswatch/ifs/low/newsid_4670000/newsid_4679000/4679018.stm | accessdate = 30 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = NewsWatch: BBC's dilemma over cartoons | work=[[BBC News Online]] | date = 3 February 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/newswatch/ifs/low/newsid_4670000/newsid_4678100/4678186.stm | accessdate = 30 January 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Muslim jokes 'scare' BBC – Elton | work=[[BBC News Online]] | date = 2 April 2008 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7326476.stm | accessdate = 30 January 2009}}</ref>
=== Climate change === The BBC has been criticised for hypocrisy over its high [[carbon footprint]], in view of the amount of coverage it gives to the topic of climate change. ''[[Newsnight]]'' presenter [[Jeremy Paxman]] argues that the Corporation's correspondents "travel the globe to tell the audience of the dangers of climate change while leaving a vapour trail which will make the problem even worse".<ref name ="GuardianGreen">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/6322259.stm |title=How green is my Auntie?|first=Jeremy|last=Paxman|authorlink=Jeremy Paxman|date=2 February 2007|accessdate=24 January 2014|work=BBC News}}</ref> Paxman further argues that the 'BBC's coverage of the issue abandoned the pretence of impartiality long ago'.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/31/broadcasting.digitalmedia |title=Paxman accuses BBC of hypocrisy over environment|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=31 January 2007|accessdate=24 January 2014|first=Jason|last=Deans}}</ref>
At the 2007 [[Edinburgh International Television Festival]], [[Peter Horrocks]] (Head of TV News) and [[Peter Barron]] (Editor, ''[[Newsnight]]''), said that the BBC should not campaign on the issue of climate change. They criticised proposed plans for a BBC [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]-style day of programmes around climate change. Horrocks was quoted as saying: "I absolutely don't think we should do that because it's not impartial. It's not our job to lead people and proselytise about it."
Peter Barron was quoted as adding: "It is absolutely not the BBC's job to save the planet. I think there are a lot of people who think that, but it must be stopped."<ref>[http://media.guardian.co.uk/bbc/story/0,,2162901,00.html], BBC Drops Climate Change Special, Media Guardian, 5 September</ref>
Peter Horrocks later outlined the BBC's position on the BBC Editors Blog ("No Line").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/theeditors/2007/08/no_line.html |title=BBC Editors Blog |date=30 August 2007 |accessdate=24 January 2014|first=Peter |last=Horrocks |authorlink=Peter Horrocks |work=[[BBC News Online]]}}</ref>
The plans for a day of programmes about environmental issues were abandoned in September 2007. A BBC spokesperson said this was "absolutely not" because of concerns about impartiality.<ref name="GuardianGreen"/>
In July 2011 a BBC Trust review cited findings of an assessment by Professor Steve Jones of [[University College London]]. Jones found there was an at times "over-rigid" application of the Editorial Guidelines on impartiality in relation to science coverage, which failed to take into account what he regarded as the "non-contentious" nature of some stories and the need to avoid giving "undue attention to marginal opinion". Professor Jones gave reporting of the safety of the [[MMR vaccine]] and more recent coverage of claims about the safety of GM crops and the existence of man made climate change as examples of his point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/our_work/science_impartiality/science_impartiality.pdf |title=BBC Trust review of impartiality and accuracy of the BBC's coverage of science|format=PDF |date= July 2011|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> In 2017, the [[BBC]] apologised for allowing climate change denier [[Nigel Lawson|Lord Lawson]] to falsely claim that global temperatures had not risen in the past decade on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s [[Today (BBC Radio 4)|''Today Programme'']] (which the organisation acknowledged breached its editorial guidelines<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carrington |first1=Damian |title=BBC apologises over interview with climate denier Lord Lawson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/24/bbc-apologises-over-interview-climate-sceptic-lord-nigel-lawson |accessdate=14 September 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=24 October 2017}}</ref>) and in 2018, [[Carbon Brief]] released an internal notice sent by [[Fran Unsworth]], BBC director of news and current affairs, arguing that the BBC's coverage of climate change often went against its own guidelines on accuracy and created a [[false balance]] with regard to impartiality stating: "Manmade climate change exists: If the science proves it we should report it. … To achieve impartiality, you do not need to include outright deniers of climate change in BBC coverage, in the same way you would not have someone denying that Manchester United won 2-0 last Saturday. The referee has spoken."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carrington |first1=Damian |title=BBC admits 'we get climate change coverage wrong too often' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/sep/07/bbc-we-get-climate-change-coverage-wrong-too-often |accessdate=14 September 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 September 2018}}</ref>
The BBC is alleged to have attempted to cover up a climate change seminar credited with shaping its coverage of the environment.<ref>{{cite news|last=Paton|first=Graeme|title=Row over BBC climate change conference 'cover up'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/10566952/Row-over-BBC-climate-change-conference-cover-up.html|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=12 January 2014|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
=== Anti-Catholic bias ===
Prominent Roman Catholic leaders have criticised the BBC for having an anti-Catholic bias and showing hostility towards the Roman Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite news | first = Claire | last = Cozens | title = BBC accused of 'gross insensitivity' to Catholics | date = 4 February 2004 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/feb/04/bbc.religion |work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=British bishops group accuses BBC of bias against Catholics|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2003-10-18/news/0310180237_1_bishops-group-contraception-and-abortion-anti-catholic-bias|accessdate=31 October 2012|work=Chicago Tribune|date=18 October 2003}}</ref>
The BBC has also been criticised for recycling old news and for "insensitivity" and bad timing when it decided to broadcast programmes called ''Kenyon Confronts'' and ''Sex and the Holy City'' around the same time as [[Pope John Paul II]]'s 25th anniversary and the beatification of [[Mother Teresa]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Archbishop meets BBC over 'bias'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/3172408.stm|accessdate=31 October 2012|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=7 October 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Watts|first=Greg|title=Bishops Accuse BBC Of Anti-Catholic Bias|url=http://www.ncregister.com/site/article/5660|accessdate=31 October 2012|work=National Catholic Register|date=28 March 2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908163150/http://www.ncregister.com/site/article/5660|archivedate=8 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BBC accused of anti-Catholic bias|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/3148708.stm|accessdate=31 October 2012|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=29 September 2003}}</ref>
In 2003, the BBC had planned ''[[Popetown]]'', a ten-part cartoon series which "featured an infantile Pope [...] bouncing around the Vatican on a pogostick". The plans were shelved after it evoked intense outrage and criticism from Roman Catholics.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bates|first=Stephen|title=BBC drops controversial Pope cartoon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/sep/24/bbc.broadcasting|accessdate=31 October 2012|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 September 2004}}</ref>
=== Documentary on Euro 2012 ===
Eleven days before the tournament took place, the [[BBC]] [[Current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] programme ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'', entitled ''[[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]]: Stadiums of Hate'', included recent footage of supporters chanting various racist slogans and displays of [[white power]] symbols and banners in Poland, and Nazi salutes and the beating of South Asians in Ukraine.<ref name="campbell">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18192375 | title=Sol Campbell warns fans to stay away from Euro 2012 | publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |work=BBC News | date=28 May 2012 | accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref> The documentary was first commented widely in the British press, but then accused of being one-sided, biased and unethical. Critics included the British media; anti-racism campaigners, and black and Jewish community leaders in Poland; Polish and Ukrainian politicians and journalists; England fans visiting the host nations and footballers ([[Gary Lineker]], [[Roy Hodgson]] and others).<ref name="http">{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2012/06/ugly-spectre |author="K. T."| work=[[The Economist]] | title=Euro 2012 is overshadowed by accusations of racism and anti-Semitism|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="economist.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2012/06/poland-and-bbc | work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 June 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014| title=Stitch up unstitched—updated (again)|author="K. T."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/Football/Unfair-say-organisers/Article1-863192.aspx |title=‘Unfair’ say organisers |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=14 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201153444/http://www.hindustantimes.com/sports-news/Football/Unfair-say-organisers/Article1-863192.aspx |archivedate=1 December 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Jonathan Ornstein]], the leader of Jewish community in Kraków, a Jewish source used in the documentary said: "I am furious at the way the BBC has exploited me as a source. The organization used me and others to manipulate the serious subject of anti-Semitism for its own sensationalist agenda... the BBC knowingly cheated its own audience - the British people - by concocting a false horror story about Poland. In doing so, the BBC has spread fear, ignorance, prejudice and hatred. I am profoundly disturbed by this unethical form of journalism."<ref name="http"/>
A reporter from ''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'', Poland's biggest left-wing newspaper, questioned ''Panorama'''s practices and said: "I am becoming more and more surprised with what the BBC says. So far it has denied two situations I witnessed. I would not be surprised if the BBC prepared a statement saying that the ''Panorama'' crew has never been to Poland."<ref name="economist.com"/>
An anti-racism campaigner Jacek Purski said: "The material prepared by the BBC is one-sided. It does not show the whole story of Polish preparations for the Euros. It does not show the Championship ran a lot of activities aimed at combating racism in the "Respect Diversity" campaign. For us the Euro is not only about matches. The event has become an opportunity to fight effectively against racism and promote multiculturalism. There is no country in Europe free from racism. These are the facts."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://krakow.gazeta.pl/krakow/1,44425,11824886,Wszyscy_jestesmy_odpowiedzialni_za_pseudokibicow.html |title=Wszyscy jesteśmy odpowiedzialni za pseudokibiców |work=Krakow.gazeta.pl |date=20 May 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014|first=Magdalena |last=Wójcik |language=Polish }}</ref>
The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that the Football Association intended to write a letter of complaint to the BBC.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-2163407/Euro-2012-FA-set-rap-Panorama-race-scare--Charles-Sale.html | work=[[Daily Mail]] | first=Charles | last=Sale | title=FA set to rap Panorama after race scare show |accessdate=24 January 2014 |date=22 June 2012}}</ref>
The nations fined by [[UEFA]] for racism were not the hosts but the visitors from Spain, Croatia, Russia<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/euro2012/article-2166926/Euro-2012-Ukraine-chief-blasts-Sol-Campbell.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=Euro 2012: Ukraine chief blasts Sol Campbell|work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=30 June 2012 |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref> and Germany.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/06/26/sport/football/euro-2012-germany-fined/index.html |title=Germany fined after soccer fans wear neo-Nazi symbols |work=CNN |date= 26 June 2012|accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> The [[Royal Dutch Football Association]] issued a complaint to UEFA after [[monkey chants]] were thought to be aimed at their black players, during an open training session in [[Kraków]]. UEFA denied the chants were racially motivated.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jun/07/euro-2012-holland-racist-abuse |title=Holland players subjected to racist abuse at training session |work=[[The Guardian]] |date= 7 June 2012|accessdate=19 January 2014}}</ref>
=== Sexual abuse scandals and their implications === {{main article|Jimmy Savile sexual abuse scandal|North Wales child abuse scandal}} In the weeks after the [[ITV1]] documentary ''[[Exposure (UK TV series)|Exposure]]: The Other Side of Jimmy Savile'' was broadcast on 3 October 2012, the BBC faced questions and criticism over allegations that it had failed to act on rumours about sexual assaults, especially on young girls, by presenter [[Jimmy Savile]], some of which had occurred on BBC premises after the recording of programmes including ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' and ''[[Jim'll Fix It]]''. Allegations were also made that a ''[[Newsnight]]'' investigation into Savile in December 2011 was dropped because it conflicted with tribute programmes prepared after Savile's death.
By 11 October 2012 allegations of abuse by Savile had been made to 13 British police forces,<ref>{{cite news|first=Martin|last=Evans|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9601922/Sir-Jimmy-Savile-fourth-British-TV-personality-accused-in-sex-allegations.html|title=Sir Jimmy Savile: fourth British TV personality accused in sex allegations|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=11 October 2012|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> and on 19 October [[Metropolitan Police Service|Scotland Yard]] launched a formal criminal investigation into historic allegations of child sex abuse by Savile and others over four decades.<ref name="bbc191012">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20006049|title=Savile abuse claims: Met Police launch criminal inquiry|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=19 October 2012|accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="telegraph 191012">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/jimmy-savile/9620149/Jimmy-Savile-police-launch-criminal-investigation-after-victims-claim-some-abusers-are-still-alive.html|title=Jimmy Savile: police launch criminal investigation after victims claim some abusers are still alive|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=19 October 2012|accessdate=19 October 2012|first=Gordon|last=Rayner}}</ref> The police reported on 25 October 2012 that the number of possible victims was 300.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20081021|title= Jimmy Savile: Number of victims reach 300, police say|date=25 October 2012|work=[[BBC News Online]]|accessdate=25 October 2012}}</ref>
